title: AB 1673
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 16520 of the Penal Code is amended to define a "firearm" as a device designed for use as a weapon that expels a projectile through a barrel by the force of an explosion or combustion. The definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in various sections of the code. The Penal Code includes various sections that define a "firearm" and its components. It also specifies that certain devices containing explosive materials are considered firearms. Additionally, antique firearms are excluded from the definition in specific sections of the code. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" and its components in various sections, including specific exclusions for antique firearms and unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device designed to expel a projectile through a barrel by the force of an explosion. It includes the frame or receiver of the weapon, as specified in certain sections. The Penal Code lists various sections that define the term "firearm" and include devices like rockets or launchers with explosive materials. The Penal Code lists specific sections that exclude unloaded antique firearms from the definition of a "firearm", as well as sections that exclude destructive devices from the definition in certain contexts. The Penal Code excludes certain firearms from the definition of a "firearm" in various sections, including unfinished frames or receivers that can be easily converted to a functional state. The Penal Code defines a "firearm" as a device designed to expel a projectile through a barrel by the force of an explosion. It includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in specific sections, such as Section 16550, Section 16730, Section 16960, Section 16990, and Section 17070. The Penal Code lists various sections that define the term "firearm," including provisions related to rockets and explosive devices. These sections include 16550, 16730, 16960, 16990, 17070, and others. Additionally, certain sections expand the definition of "firearm" to include rocket launchers and similar devices, such as Section 16750, Section 16840(b), and Section 25400. The Penal Code lists various sections defining the term "firearm," including rocket launchers and explosive devices. Sections 16750, 16840(b), and 25400 expand this definition. Additionally, certain provisions exclude unloaded antique firearms from the definition in specific sections. In the Penal Code, various sections define the term "firearm," including rocket launchers and explosive devices. Sections 29010 to 29150, 25135, and 29180 further clarify the definition. Additionally, certain provisions exclude certain firearms from specific sections. In the Penal Code, the term "firearm" is defined as a device designed for weapon use that expels a projectile through a barrel by combustion. This definition includes the frame or receiver of the weapon in specific sections. The Penal Code lists various sections that define the term "firearm" to include devices like rockets or launchers containing explosive material. The Penal Code lists specific sections where the term "firearm" excludes unloaded antique firearms, as well as sections where it does not include destructive devices. In Sections 29010 to 29150, firearm includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to finished condition. In Sections 29010 to 29150, firearm includes unfinished frames or receivers that can be converted to finished condition. As used in this section, "frame" and "receiver" refer to the part of a firearm housing the firing mechanism and barrel, including blanks or machined bodies designed for further processing into functional weapons. Section 1.1 of the bill incorporates amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of Senate Bill 894 and certain conditions being met. Section 1.2 of the bill includes amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, dependent on the enactment of specific bills and conditions being met by January 1, 2017. Section 1.3 of the bill incorporates amendments to Section 16520 of the Penal Code, contingent on the enactment of specific bills by January 1, 2017. No reimbursement required by this act under California Constitution as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
